utterance: Bethany McGregor: of the caribou in Northern Canada, they found that insect populations actually drive these caribou migrations. You know, insect pressure can drive animals to move quite a bit. And then you're not just talking about the insects because then you also have to consider all of the factors that go into where those insects are at and why they're at the populations that they're at that are driving those movements. So you get many layers deep in the complexity of what's driving movement patterns in these different groups and I I feel like it's going to be very challenging to do a broad generalization on that.

annotations.develop idea: The speaker is expanding on the idea that insect populations drive caribou migrations, providing examples and explaining the complexity of factors involved.
annotations.identify gap: The speaker notes the complexity of the issue and implies a gap in knowledge by stating it will be challenging to make a broad generalization.

utterance: Daniel Becker: Yeah, I think about um probably migration as kind of as the main movement thing that I I work on but you know, thinking of that as a very specialized form of a general movement process that's just seasonal regular movement and you know, kind of at simplest that can just be governed by, you know, like when you when you depart your wintering grounds, when you depart your breeding grounds and the the distance it takes to connect those two areas is kind of one generalizable framework you can think of and then sort of you know the the parameterization of the timing and and distance kind of governs like the the base you know movement cycle that then we can layer any kind of disease process on top of. Um so I think there's some some big generality there that you can then sort of you know add whatever complexity you need to. Um but it's kind of a nice a nice starting point I guess.

annotations.develop idea: The speaker expands on existing ideas by providing a framework for understanding movement processes as a generalizable phenomenon, building on the previous discussion.
annotations.propose new idea: The speaker introduces a new perspective on migration as a specialized form of a general movement process, offering a framework for modeling movements.

utterance: Guillaume Bastille-Rousseau: I I agree with uh with what you just said Daniel about that. I think from a modeling perspective there's a lot of generalization I think we can do. But even with migration, I will say that uh I mean it's very what's driving the actual migration or the factor that are determining the timing of that migration is could be very system and even like within ungulate species will be fairly can be fairly different. So uh yes, I think this I I still struggle to see like if we want to move toward generalize I think the only way we can move towards more generalizable models like for movement is to we need to move away from like specific kind of environmental co areas and more moving towards like more like first principles like well every animal move well most of them move in response to foraging but what is foraging for them is very different depending on the system you deal like what system you're dealing with. So it's somehow we still need to we can make them general generalizable but we still need to have that system specific insights before being able to get at that to an extent.

annotations.identify gap: Guillaume highlights the gap in current modeling approaches, emphasizing the need for system-specific insights to improve generalizability.

So there's these different dimensions of movement too um that might be more important when we think about how do they influence disease and kind of wondering if those aspects are also generalizable rather than maybe other movement motifs that may might not be as important for um transmission or something along those lines.

utterance: Kezia Manlove: I guess I think that our information gap is not the biggest information gap, the most critical information gap with respect to movement is not our ability to sense environmental covariance. It is our ability to wall wall color everybody or alternatively to be able to predict contact in some other way. And then also we need a better handle on what's going on within the host, right? We take these hosts, we don't, you know, like when I work on megafauna, right? So we catch an animal, we get one cross-sectional sample, we can we are not calibrated to forecast disease dynamics well or or internal state well within the animal. And so we don't know how susceptibility is varying. So I think that in my mind at least, the information gap surrounding where everyone else is and what's actually happening in the animal seem like way bigger um obstacles than improved remote sensing. However, maybe there's a way to remotely sense moving animals without instrumenting them. That would be awesome.

utterance: Daniel Becker (University of Oklahoma): Again, sorry, sorry, harp on migration a bit, but the point about radar detection I think is a really exciting area for at least getting a sense of um when animals leave or when they arrive, right? utterance: Bethany McGregor USDA ARS: Yeah, I wish there was a way, uh, so, so like I said when I introduced myself, I do a lot of blood meal analysis where, you know, I take a blood fed insect and I can tell you what it fed on. So, I mean, I think there is a possibility with using blood engorged insects to do some degree of monitoring, but I don't know how useful that is for small scale movement.

And we came up with, you know, a big limitation which is we don't even have open access data to really mine and and come up with these general patterns that might be there that could help you understand um some of the phenomena on on scalability, different animals or even humans, you know, which is what we were working on. Um, so I agree with this the big challenge is how can you translate from individual studies and and and settings to a trend of mobility, exposure and and I guess emergence. So we had to individually track all the dogs and see that they had common areas in the, you know, crop area next to the park where the chimpanzees are going and the dogs are meeting. utterance: Mike Wimberly: If I could just uh quickly interject, I've I've been listening and you definitely have a some themes emerging here. I I think in terms of the scale issue, you know, I'm hearing a lot of consensus about the value of, you know, individual animal level studies. Um, you know, potentially there's value even in, you know, doing more of those tracking individual animals uh, you know, over time in terms of uh, you know, maybe infection by various pathogens. And you you know, there's a need for, you know, those very detailed uh and precise measurements to often, you know, to be able to disentangle uh the complexities of a local disease transmission cycle. Um, often, you know, the specific characteristics of that will not extrapolate to other areas, but I think there's a big potential for gaining a better understanding of important mechanisms that are, you know, that are often broadly more important beyond an individual system. the other thing I I kind of hear everyone kind of also sort of maybe almost using that as a reference point but stretching toward this idea, you know, toward the the fuzzier picture of you know, what types of data, what framework do we need for a you know, maybe something in the context of much larger scale continental to global surveillance.
